botanical_details.genus: Viola can be annuals, biennials or deciduous or evergreen perennials, with simple or pinnately lobed leaves and 5-petalled flowers of characteristic shape
botanical_details.horticultural_group: Violas are compact reliably perennial, clump-forming plants with a complex root system and rounded, more or less fragrant flowers, often with darker rays, over a long period in late spring and summer

how_to_grow.cultivation: Best in humus-rich, moist but well-drained soil but will grow in any, moderately fertile soil apart from waterlogged soils. Full sun or partial shade is best but shade is tolerated
how_to_grow.propagation: Propagate by seed sown in late winter or early spring or propagate by stem-tip cuttings in spring or late summer
how_to_grow.pruning: Deadhead to prolong flowering unless seed is required. Cut back after flowering in summer
how_to_grow.pests: May be attacked by slugs, snails, aphids, glasshouse red spider mite and violet gall midge
how_to_grow.diseases: May be subject to powdery mildews, pansy leaf spot, a virus and a rust
